elements.title: Atomic Network Assembly Speed Validation
elements.problem: If the match-first onboarding is too slow or requires too many steps, agent-recruited hosts will default to direct dealing before the atomic network forms.
elements.solution: Measure the end-to-end time from magic link delivery to first deal acceptance for agent-recruited hosts.

evidence.insight: The one-week deadline is the hard constraint. Validation must prove the flow completes well within this window.

elements.test_description: Track the funnel: magic link sent -> link opened -> match reviewed -> account created -> deal accepted. Measure time between each step and overall time-to-deal.
elements.success_criteria: Median time from link-open to deal-acceptance under 24 hours. 50%+ of agent-recruited hosts complete the flow within 7 days. Link-to-match-view conversion above 70%.
elements.failure_meaning: If time-to-deal exceeds 7 days, the single-session flow has too much friction or the match quality is insufficient. If link-to-match-view is below 70%, the magic link is not reaching hosts or is being ignored.
elements.implementation_hint: Analytics events: magic_link_sent, magic_link_opened, match_viewed, account_created, deal_accepted. Calculate cohort-based funnel metrics weekly. Alert Bryant (agent) if a host opens the link but doesn't complete within 48 hours.

elements.title: Dual Verification Transparency Usability Test
elements.problem: If hosts can't find both platform verification and personal guest documents in a single view, they'll either bypass the platform (contact guests directly) or reject proposals out of insufficient information.
elements.solution: Run a task-based usability test where hosts review a proposal and are asked: 'What do you know about this guest? Where would you find their ID?'

evidence.quote: Still have their information, their driver's license.
evidence.insight: The test must verify that hosts can locate personal documents within the platform UI, not just see verification badges.

elements.test_description: 5-8 participants who match the 'experienced host' profile. Task: Review a guest proposal. Questions: (1) Do you feel comfortable accepting? Why/why not? (2) Where would you find the guest's ID? (3) What did Split Lease verify? Follow-up: Compare time-to-confidence with vs. without the dual-track display.
elements.success_criteria: 80%+ of participants can locate guest personal documents within 2 taps. 70%+ report higher confidence with dual-track display vs. badge-only display. Average time to 'comfortable to accept' decision under 3 minutes.
elements.failure_meaning: If hosts can't find documents, the information hierarchy is wrong (documents are too deeply nested). If confidence doesn't increase with the dual-track display, the evidence shown isn't meaningful to hosts.
elements.implementation_hint: Prototype the dual-track verification display in Figma. Recruit 5 hosts who have previously managed direct subleases. Record screen and think-aloud. Focus on the moment of 'I feel comfortable' or 'I need more info.'

elements.title: Remote Host Digest Engagement Validation
elements.problem: If the weekly digest is not opened, the remote host loses the engagement loop and either contacts tenants directly or builds unchecked anxiety.
elements.solution: Track digest open rates, click-through to app, and correlation with platform bypass (direct host-tenant communication outside the platform).

evidence.insight: The digest is the primary engagement mechanism for overseas hosts. Its effectiveness determines whether the host stays on-platform.

elements.test_description: For all hosts whose timezone differs from their property's timezone by 4+ hours: track weekly digest open rate, time-to-open (from send), click-through to app, and whether the host contacted the tenant directly (off-platform) in the same week.
elements.success_criteria: Digest open rate above 60% for remote hosts. Time-to-open under 12 hours. Platform bypass rate (off-platform communication detected or reported) below 20%.
elements.failure_meaning: Low open rate: digest content is not valuable enough or delivery time is wrong. High bypass rate: the digest doesn't answer the host's core question ('is my apartment okay?'), so they seek answers elsewhere.
elements.implementation_hint: Email analytics: track opens, clicks. Correlate with in-app engagement on the same day. Survey remote hosts quarterly: 'Did you contact your tenant directly this month? If so, why?'

elements.title: Language Translation Comprehension Test
elements.problem: If platform terminology confuses experienced hosts, they'll either misunderstand what they're agreeing to or abandon the process out of frustration.
elements.solution: A/B test the agreement review page: Version A uses platform terminology ('custom rental agreement,' 'proposal,' 'guest'). Version B uses host-native terminology ('your sublease agreement,' 'rental interest,' 'tenant'). Measure comprehension and completion.

evidence.quote: Standard sublease agreement... custom rental agreement... supplemental agreement.
evidence.insight: Three unfamiliar terms in 22 seconds caused confusion. The test must validate whether translated language improves comprehension.

elements.test_description: A/B test on the agreement review page. Group A: platform terminology. Group B: translated host-native terminology. Track: time on page, completion rate, support ticket rate, and post-completion comprehension quiz (3 questions about what they agreed to).
elements.success_criteria: Group B shows 20%+ higher completion rate and 30%+ fewer 'what does this mean' support tickets. Comprehension quiz scores 80%+ in Group B.
elements.failure_meaning: If no difference between groups, the vocabulary mismatch is not the primary barrier â€” something else (trust, complexity, visual design) is the issue.
elements.implementation_hint: Create two versions of the agreement review page text. Use feature flags to split traffic 50/50. Track analytics events: page_view, agreement_accepted, support_ticket_opened. Run for 2 months or 200 completions, whichever comes first.

elements.title: Journey-Level Atomic Network Formation Rate
elements.problem: Individual elements may test well in isolation, but the full atomic network formation requires all elements to work together: match presentation + verification + speed + emotional tone must combine to convert a skeptical host into a first deal.
elements.solution: Track the atomic network formation rate: the percentage of agent-recruited hosts who complete their first deal through the platform (not through direct dealing bypassing the platform).

evidence.quote: The atomic network is the smallest possible network where there are enough people for the product to become useful.
evidence.insight: The journey-level metric is: did the atomic network form? One host + one guest + one completed deal = one atomic network. This is the fundamental health metric.

elements.test_description: For every agent-recruited host: track whether they complete a first deal within 30 days of initial contact. Segment by: deal completed through platform, deal completed outside platform (host found tenants themselves), and no deal (host didn't proceed). This is the north star metric for the Cold Start lens.
elements.success_criteria: Atomic network formation rate (first deal through platform) above 40% for agent-recruited hosts within 30 days. Platform bypass rate below 25%. No-deal rate below 35%.
elements.failure_meaning: If the formation rate is below 40%, the overall pipeline has too much friction. Identify the dropout point (match review? account creation? agreement review?) and loop back to the relevant layer. If bypass rate is above 25%, the platform is not proving sufficient value over direct dealing.
elements.implementation_hint: Cohort analysis: group hosts by week of first agent contact. Track 30-day outcome for each cohort. Dashboard showing: formation rate, bypass rate, no-deal rate, with trend lines. Review weekly in ops meeting.
